Kill the stories attached to you: who you are, who you were, who you wanted to be. Let go of these narratives to reinvent yourself in the present.
Kill the shame, kill the regret, kill the feelings that make you feel dirty. Release these emotions to free up space for current growth.
You are not your past. You are your current action. Focus on what you're doing now to define your identity.

Ten years ago, I simply didn‚Äôt have the skills I needed to keep my marriage together. There is an innocence there that is easy to forgive. Recognize unskillfulness in your past actions rather than moral failings to make forgiveness easier.

Seeing that I behaved unskillfully allows me to take responsibility for mistakes that I made, rather than clinging to my judgments and justifications. At the same time, it helps me not let my mistakes define who I am. Accountability prevents past errors from overshadowing your present self.
Acceptance is the precursor to atonement. Accept the past and its messiness to shift your gaze away from old regrets and focus on the present.

Regrets are normal and they mean that you care about living a good life. That painful feeling is like the rumble strip on the side of the road that buzzes when you‚Äôre drifting‚Äîthe feeling of regret is a warning to straighten out your course right now.
The best time to plant a tree was 40 years ago; the next best time is now. Channel the energy of regret into immediate action to build the life you want.

If you're drowning in shame for something you did, incorporate support to let go: Tell God, tell a friend, use the experience to share with others or to teach. Replace self-loathing with compassion for long-term motivation.
Self-forgiveness requires striking a balance between taking responsibility and maintaining a positive sense of self. When you find this equilibrium, you reach self-forgiveness and can move forward.

The three pillars of self-forgiveness: Release of negative emotions directed toward the self, cultivation of positive emotions directed toward the self, and acceptance of responsibility for past actions.

When we do something bad, wrong, or against our values, we may be greeted with painful, negative emotions such as shame, guilt, resentment, or anger. Self-forgiveness does not mean we skip feeling bad; it means we work through these feelings and relieve ourselves of them once they‚Äôve served their purpose.

The four Rs of genuine self-forgiveness: 1. Responsibility‚Äîtake it without blaming others. 2. Remorse‚Äîwork through shame to guilt that motivates repair. 3. Restoration‚Äîactively make things right and repair relationships. 4. Renewal‚Äîrecommit to your values and act in accordance with them now.

Obsessing over the past and future are defense mechanisms of the ego. The only time that is real is now. The moment is what is real. Make smaller goals to cascade into larger accomplishments and move forward.
If you don't leave the pity party, you'll find yourself older and regretting not acting now. It's a shame cycle‚Äîbreak it by setting achievable goals and focusing on contentment in the present.

Focus on small things day to day: healthy breakfast, gym, hobbies, cleaning. Direct your mind to what you can control now, not the unchangeable past. Hold on to hope while becoming the person you want to be.
Practice catching yourself when you start to dwell and remind yourself that what matters is what's helpful to you now. Take action to help your future self avoid more regrets in this moment.
You can't keep blaming yourself. Just blame yourself once, and move on.
The past is the past, and it is a part of you, but you determine how: a shameful secret that pains you, or a lesson you learned and grew from. Show compassion and forgiveness to your past self.
Let it go if it doesn‚Äôt serve you. Don't beat yourself up forever‚Äîaccept it happened and focus on being the best person you can be now.
Forgive yourself and practice some self-compassion. Talk to a trusted person or therapist to avoid letting shame swallow you‚Äîground yourself in the present.
